Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is in providing a more sustainable, low-cost water management system capable of purifying, or treating, wastewater produced through a wide array of applications, ranging from agriculture to manufacturing. The core technology incorporates an efficient, passive solar thermal harvesting technique for capturing thermal energy. The successful development, commercialization and incorporation of this modular system into existing wastewater systems could reduce costs and increase efficiency in wastewater management, creation of renewable fresh water, and the handling of potentially hazardous wastewater.

This I-Corps project provides a high-rate, high-efficiency transformative distillation method that localizes radiation heat within porous media. This passive method for water distillation utilizes stored radiative thermal energy for collecting distilled water from wastewater. Unlike existing methods of distillation where the bulk of the body of liquid is heated for evaporation/boiling, this technology focuses the stored heat onto a thin layer of liquid and allows the rest of the bulk liquid to remain unheated, leading to maximum efficiency and phase-change rate. A physical model has been developed, and laboratory testing under typical solar radiation intensity conditions has shown encouraging results. Through this I-Corps project, this method of distillation can be investigated to determine whether it will lead to the more effective and economical management of industrial wastewater and agricultural runoff.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our team (Divya Jaladi, EL; Ethan Languri, PI; Bob Piras, IM) interviewed 150 potential customers related to our customer segments, 97% of them face-to-face, as part of the customer  discovery process to determine the need for particular water management projects. Out of 150 interviews, 114 were performed during the seven-week national cohort in Los Angeles, CA, with an additional 36 conducted after the national cohort. The major goal of the interviews was to learn about the potential customer segments, using the Business Model Canvas as the test criteria.  

At the beginning of the national cohort, our team had an initial set of hypotheses based on two different customer segments: manufacturers and farmers with water-management concerns. Using data from interviews and guidance from cohort instructors, our team decided to confine our focus to only hydroponic farmers? humidification management. In our targeted interviews and data collection, we tried to determine the drawbacks of the current humidification systems and what were the farmers? needs and potential benefits they were seeking in future systems.

The main concern of most farmers and plant managers is finding an economical way to maintain the humidification set point in hydroponic greenhouses required to support the quality and quantity of the crop year-round. This piece of data from our interviews helped us realize that our idea is value-based, focused on meeting the energy-saving needs that are crucial to small- and medium-sized growers.

Furthermore, the interview data, cohort interaction, and guidance from the teaching team allowed us to test and modify the hypotheses several times, thereby validating our data and updating our value propositions. This helped us to pinpoint our customer segments to hydroponic and aquaponic subtypes of controlled farming, which allowed us to develop a more customized approach with interviewees.

Through the knowledge and field experience gained from this process, our team, built on members with technological experience, analyzed the market size and determined that there was a scalable business opportunity. As next steps, our team plans to continue these efforts and collaborate with a local hydroponic farm in testing a minimum viable product (MVP) and begin a customer validation process.
